awd_titl_txt: Strategies toward Hierarchy and Compositional Complexity in Metal Nanocrystal Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Nature is awe-inspiring for the intricate and hierarchical forms adopted by many of its materials; Such complex structures give rise to the properties that make many materials useful. Professor Skrabalak and her research group at Indiana University are developing chemical processes that introduce structural complexity to modern nanomaterials. This objective arises because the size, shape, and spatial arrangement of nanoscale materials dictate their properties. This research is expanding the synthetic toolkit in order to achieve nanomaterials by design for applications in energy conversion, catalysis, plasmonics, secured electronics, nanomedicine, and more.  This multidisciplinary project provides to graduate and undergraduate students (including members of underrepresented groups) research opportunities and training in a range of synthetic, analytical, and imaging techniques. In addition, the research team is collaborating with science educators at WonderLab - a children's science museum in Bloomington, Indiana - to provide an interactive display that teaches about nanoscience through art.  Professor Skrabalak also writes tutorials for the Joint US-Africa Materials Institute (JUAMI). These tutorials include lectures on nanomaterials for ~60 East African PhD students and U.S. participants.

With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, the Skrabalak group is developing synthetic tools in order to achieve nanostructures with unprecedented hierarchy and compositional complexity. Three aims are being addressed. The first objective is to demonstrate sequential seeded growth as a general route toward nanocrystals with different hierarchies and chiralities. The second objective is to synthesize new bimetallic heterostructures with high refractive index sensitivity and structural stability through the use of kinetically controlled deposition routes on shape-controlled seeds. The third objective is to elucidate the mechanism of galvanic replacement between intermetallic seeds to access new trimetallic compositions and heterostructures with intermetallic domains. The optical, plasmonic, and catalytic properties of achieved nanostructures are being examined in order to elucidate how complex structure and composition contribute to a material's properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The intricacy and hierarchical structure of snowflakes is astounding and emulating such structural complexity in modern materials is a central objective of nanoscience. This objective arises because the properties of nanomaterials depend on particle size, shape, and their spatial arrangement relative to one another. NSF Award 1904499 “Strategies toward Hierarchy and Compositional Complexity in Metal Nanocrystal Synthesis” provided resources to address the grand synthetic challenge of predictably achieving nanoscale materials with compositional and structural complexity while maintaining the monodispersity required to exploit their structure-dependent properties. Several concepts were demonstrated. First, sequential seeded growth was demonstrated as a general route toward nanocrystals with different hierarchies, much like the form of snowflakes but achieved by chemical methods rather than physical methods. Second, seeded methods were used to achieve chiral nanocrystals and nanocrystals with regioselective depositions, both examples of where the high symmetry of initial seeds was reduced in a defined manner to structures with lower symmetry. Finally, galvanic replacement between bimetallic seeds and metal precursors gave access to trimetallic nanocrystals and other heterostructures with complex structural features. Each of these demonstrations was made possible because seeds, much like a stick is used to nucleate sugar when making rock candy, serve as preferential sites for the deposition of additional material.

This award also enabled the study of how composition and structure influence the properties of metal nanocrystals. As one example, gold-palladium nanocrystals were shown to have among the highest ensemble sensitivity to changes in refractive index (environment) for nanocrystals with localized surface plasmon resonances in the visible region, with that sensitivity depending on the position of the palladium in the nanocrystals. They also display high thermal and photothermal stability compared to all-gold nanostructures.

This project led to 13 peer-reviewed publications in top-tier journals at grant closure. Moreover, 11 PhD students, 1 MS student, 1 visiting student, and 2 undergraduates were trained fully or in-part through this project, with nearly 50% of participants being women. PhD students have achieved top industrial positions or postdoctoral positions upon graduation, with the one graduated undergraduate researcher involved in this project pursuing a PhD in chemistry now. Also, an interactive touchscreen activity based on metal nanoparticles and art was developed in collaboration with Indiana University’s Advanced Visualization Laboratory and educational staff at Wonderlab, a science museum for children based in Bloomington, Indiana; this activity was launched on the group’s website during the height of the pandemic and used as virtual component of Indiana University’s Science Fest. Professor Skrabalak chaired the Noble Metal Nanoparticle Gordon Research Conference in 2022, which is a premier conference for research on this topic.

Ultimately, this research provided design criteria for the synthesis of hierarchical nanocrystals and nanocrystals with reduced yet defined symmetries and complex compositions through seeded methods. The new nanostructures achieved are providing new opportunities in plasmonics. This research also forged links between scientific disciplines that include nanoscience, inorganic and solid-state chemistry, condensed matter physics, surface science, and material science by providing novel nanostructure platforms to study the impact of composition and structure on properties.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/30/2023
Modified by: Sara Skrabalak
